newsitem.title: MOROCCO: PRESS DIGEST - Morocco economic weeklies - March 7.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Morocco economic weeklies - March 7.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Morocco's economic press. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Interior and agriculture ministries to assess effects of wheat import liberalisation. Cheap prices on international markets threaten local output. "Massive imports could have been avoided if dialogue and protective tariffs had been set," an official said.
- Public works ministry to devote 62 million dirhams ($6.6 million) over two years for infrastructure in the southern region hit by floods in August 1995 which killed more than 200 people.

- Head of Rabat prefectural council says no agenda set for mooted 30-year concession to Spanish-Portuguese consortium for water and electricity distribution. City's main party says there is no need to resort to concession since Rabat's grid has no major problems.

- Liberalisation of wheat imports disrupts distribution channels of local wheat. Agriculture Mnister Ayoub blamed for having concluded deregulation in haste. Going ahead will only deepen crisis as excess 700,000 tonnes wheat stock still awaits clearance.

- General Confederation of Moroccan Businesses' survey on marketing policies shows it is usually firm's director who sets marketing strategy without taking account of advice of sales managers. It says half the companies do not work with advertising agencies and 15 percent do not have marketing staff.
- Mourad Cherif, Director of Office Cherifien des Phosphates, says China is potential market for Moroccan phosphates.

- Biggest private holding ONA group ponders new approach in agro-industry sector. It plans to reinforce partnership with farmers, control raw materials costs, diversify and raise level of products so that they comply with international standards and are able to face competition.

- Leading Bank Banque Marocaine du Commerce Exterieur shows net results of 366 million dirhams in 1996 ($38.9 million) compared with 301 million the year before. Shares in BMCE which is listed on Stock Exchange have increased to 491 dirhams from 400 in two months since the start of 1997.
